situation: Used --dangerously-skip-permissions when spawning Claude from Carlton to avoid permission prompts blocking a non-interactive process
learning: Don't bypass safety. Drop -p so Claude runs interactively — user approves permissions once, they save to settings.json, future runs are automatic

situation: Stored reply files in project root (tmp/, carlton-reply-cat.md) as loose scratch files
learning: Store structured data relative to what it belongs to (reports/<date>/responses/). Pair user replies with agent responses as numbered files. Git commit before every email send for auditability.

situation: Sam asked for shamrock and fox emojis in briefings across 10+ reply exchanges. Every previous Claude agent replied 'noted\!' or 'next time\!' but none actually changed the code in src/report.ts. Sam finally said 'Ok come on you're not updating it\!'
learning: When a user requests a formatting/style change to output, update the source code immediately — don't just acknowledge the preference in memory. The fix was a 3-line change in formatBasicReport(). Noting a preference without shipping the code change is worse than useless because it makes the user think you acted.

situation: Wrote example memory entry recommending 'skip silently' for subscription calendar errors. Sam caught this — it directly contradicts the project's core principle of surfacing failures, even in example text.
learning: Never recommend silencing errors in examples or docs. Guidance must match project values: log the error visibly and continue, don't hide it. Examples teach behavior — bad examples teach bad behavior.
